author: By Everdeen Mason
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: Battlefield Update: The entrenchments Ukraine is encountering are ‘not as strong,’ an army spokesman says.
description: THE BATTLE: Ukraine’s counteroffensive, launched in early June, aims to reclaim land in the south and east of the country. Its goal in the south is to reach the Sea of Azov and drive a wedge through Russian-occupied territory, and its main effort so far has been in the direction of the city of Melitopol. Last week, Ukrainian forces said that they had retaken the village of Robotyne, breaching the first of several tiers of formidable defenses that Russia has built in the south, and that they were moving toward another defensive line.
content: THE BATTLE: Ukraine’s counteroffensive, launched in early June, aims to reclaim land in the south and east of the country. Its goal in the south is to reach the Sea of Azov and drive a wedge through Russian-occupied territory, and its main effort so far has been in the direction of the city of Melitopol. Last week, Ukrainian forces said that they had retaken the village of Robotyne, breaching the first of several tiers of formidable defenses that Russia has built in the south, and that they were moving toward another defensive line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Dibdin
title: 6 Podcasts About the Perils (and Joys) of Modern Dating
description: As you ride the relationship roller coaster, these shows offer useful advice from both experts and fellow daters.
content: Last year marked the 10th anniversary of Tinder, the swipe-based dating app whose mainstream success completely redefined the rules of romance. The search for a soul mate is always bound to be emotionally fraught, but the digital age has intensified its most brutal aspects, and created an overabundance of options which can lead to more burnout than romantic sparks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Coco Gauff Storms Into the U.S. Open Semifinals
description: After easily beating Jelena Ostapenko, 6-0, 6-2, Gauff, 19, is now one match win away from her first career singles final at the Open.
content: Coco Gauff saluted the fans in every direction of Arthur Ashe Stadium on Tuesday, thanking them for their support through one of the easiest, but also most significant, wins of her young career. She then spread out her arms and with a big smile waved her fingers upward, as if to ask for just a little more love.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Woody Allen Finds a Decidedly Mixed Reception at the Venice Film Festival
description: The director premiered his 50th film, “Coup de Chance.” It won over critics but not protesters, who asked organizers to “turn the spotlight off of rapists.”
content: It has been six years since Woody Allen had a film released in the United States, but the Venice Film Festival was still eager to roll out the red carpet for the 87-year-old director’s latest effort. However, not everyone there welcomed the filmmaker with open arms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Peter Navarro to Face Contempt Trial Over Defiance of Jan. 6 Committee
description: A federal judge allowed the trial to proceed after finding little evidence that the former president authorized Mr. Navarro to ignore a subpoena from Congress.
content: For weeks after the 2020 election had been called, Peter Navarro, a White House adviser to President Donald J. Trump, worked closely with other senior aides to keep Mr. Trump in power for a second term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost and Christopher Cottrell
title: Caught Between China and the West, a Pacific Island Nation Ousts Its Leader
description: The prime minister of Vanuatu lost his job after he was criticized for veering too close to the West. He accuses his successor of being too cozy with China.
content: With 1,200 miles of almost empty ocean to its west and more than 7,000 miles of the same to its east, the tiny Pacific archipelago nation of Vanuatu has long sought a position of neutrality toward its faraway would-be foreign partners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: BonBon Brings Its Swedish Fish to the Upper East Side
description: Check out the candy emporium’s new shop, pick up a new filled cookie from Ladurée and more food news.
content: BonBon, the Swedish candy emporium with hundreds of choices, introduced itself to New York on the Lower East Side, then followed with a store in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. It is now opening an elaborately decorated shop on the Upper East Side. Its three partners, all natives of Sweden, are introducing their own line, a first, of gummy Swedish fish in sour flavors of wild strawberry, peach, blackberry and elderflower, plus sweet wild strawberry. There will be tastings at the new store and soon, a line of licorice treats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: Cuba Says Its Citizens Were Lured to Fight in Russia’s War in Ukraine
description: The Cuban government said it had begun criminal proceedings against a “trafficking network” that had been recruiting its citizens in both Russia and Cuba for Russia’s armed forces.
content: Cuba’s government has begun criminal proceedings against a “human trafficking network” that recruited Cuban citizens to fight in Russia’s war with Ukraine, according to the Cuban Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Back to School
description: How do you feel about a new academic year?
content: Maybe your school started back in mid-August, or maybe you’re just returning to the classroom this week. But regardless of when it began, how do you feel at the start of the 2023-24 school year? Why?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Wednesday Briefing: Ukraine’s Next Move
description: Also, India’s G20 public relations blitz.
content: Ukrainian forces are battling to break through a Russian defense line in the south near the village of Verbove, military analysts said. The push comes a week after Ukrainian forces said they had retaken the village of Robotyne, the first of several tiers of formidable defenses that Russia has built in the south.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Hong Kong Must Have Framework to Recognize Same-Sex Unions, Court Rules
description: The ruling by the city’s Court of Final Appeal stops short of recognizing same-sex marriage, but some experts see the outcome as a small step forward.
content: Hong Kong’s top court ruled on Tuesday that the city’s government must establish a framework to legally recognize same-sex partnerships, delivering a partial victory to L.G.B.T.Q. activists. The ruling underscores how Asia’s conservative landscape is evolving when it comes to gay rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Saul Austerlitz
title: Why I Love Doing Homework (Even If My Kids Hate It)
description: It’s an opportunity to walk alongside them as they commit to the work of learning.
content: My kids call me the homework villain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Consistent Signs of Erosion in Black and Hispanic Support for Biden
description: It’s a weakness that could manifest itself as low Democratic turnout even if Trump and Republicans don’t gain among those groups.
content: President Biden is underperforming among nonwhite voters in New York Times/Siena College national polls over the last year, helping to keep the race close in a hypothetical rematch against Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: N.Y.P.D. Must Rewrite Rules for Policing Protests After Sweeping Deal
description: The department agreed to stop kettling and create an oversight board for demonstrations in a legal settlement with the state attorney general, the New York Civil Liberties Union and the Legal Aid Society.
content: After years of clashes in the street and the courts, the New York Police Department has agreed to a legal settlement that will overhaul how it handles demonstrations, including banning the tactic of boxing in protesters and then arresting them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Grand in Scale
description: Alan Siegel reminds us to depend on one another.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: First Look: ‘The Color Purple’ Finds New Hues in Film Adaptation of Stage Musical
description: The director Blitz Bazawule added magical realist elements to his adaptation. But convincing Fantasia Barrino to return after Broadway took some work.
content: “The Color Purple” is a monumental, and monumentally successful, work that has taken many forms: Alice Walker’s original 1982 novel, a Pulitzer Prize winner; Steven Spielberg’s 1985 movie, an Oscar nominee many times over that launched the screen career of Whoopi Goldberg and introduced Oprah Winfrey in her first movie role; and two Tony-winning Broadway musical productions, the box-office smash original in 2005 and the revival in 2015.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Franz Lidz
title: Undying Dread: A 400-Year-Old Corpse, Locked to Its Grave
description: In 17th-century Europe, the dead were a constant threat to rise again and bedevil the living. Now archaeologists have found the remains of a suspected child revenant.
content: If reports from the time are to be believed, 17th-century Poland was awash in revenants — not vampires, exactly, but proto-zombies who harassed the living by drinking their blood or, less disagreeably, stirring up a ruckus in their homes. In one account, from 1674, a dead man rose from his tomb to assault his relatives; when his grave was opened, the corpse was unnaturally preserved and bore traces of fresh blood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: California’s Hot Labor Summer Is Not Over Yet
description: A coalition of 85,000 Kaiser Permanente employees, most of whom are based in California, have begun voting on whether to authorize a strike.
content: Summer may be on its last legs, but California’s hot labor summer certainly isn’t.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman, David Montgomery and Edgar Sandoval
title: Ken Paxton Faces Charges From Fellow Republicans at Impeachment Trial
description: The Texas attorney general pleaded not guilty to accusations of corruption and abuse of office in what is expected to be a lengthy trial in the State Senate.
content: Ken Paxton, the Republican attorney general of Texas, pleaded not guilty to charges of corruption and bribery Tuesday on the opening day of his impeachment trial before the State Senate, the first such proceeding for a statewide officer in more than a century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Yiwen Lu
title: A $700 Million Bonanza for the Winners of Crypto’s Collapse: Lawyers
description: Bankruptcy lawyers and other corporate turnaround specialists have reaped major fees from the bankruptcies of five cryptocurrency companies, including FTX.
content: The collapse in cryptocurrency prices last year forced a procession of major firms into bankruptcy, triggering a government crackdown and erasing the savings of millions of inexperienced investors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Zheng Qinwen Is Coming Into Her Own
description: Zheng, 20, has battled through four matches at the U.S. Open, improving with each win. On Wednesday, she will play Aryna Sabalenka, who is on the cusp of being the world No. 1.
content: Zheng Qinwen, the brightest of China’s growing cohort of bright tennis lights, was 7 years old when she first picked up a racket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Progressive District Attorney Enters Race to Unseat Ted Cruz
description: Mark Gonzalez, facing a conservative effort to remove him from the district attorney’s office in Nueces County, Texas, resigned and announced his campaign for the Senate.
content: Mark A. Gonzalez, a progressive district attorney in Nueces County, Texas, took an unusual tack when he came under fire from conservatives who didn’t like how he was doing his job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: Santos Talks to Prosecutors About ‘Paths Forward’ as New Evidence Looms
description: Representative George Santos and federal prosecutors asked to postpone a status conference to continue discussions on “possible paths forward” in his fraud case.
content: Representative George Santos has entered talks with federal prosecutors about “possible paths forward” in his fraud case, an indication that the parties may be considering a plea deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Picks Jack Lew as Envoy to Israel During Time of Friction
description: Mr. Lew, a former Treasury secretary, would bring stature and a low-key style to the assignment of representing the president to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government.
content: President Biden announced on Tuesday that he would nominate former Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew as his next ambassador to Israel, tapping a low-key Washington veteran for a high-charged post at a time of friction with America’s strongest ally in the Middle East.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: Fall TV Reflects the Hollywood Strikes, but Not How You Think
description: The tired familiarity of the reality-heavy network schedules is a reminder of the issues that led to the work stoppages.
content: Fall TV this year rolls in amid the fog of the writers’ and actors’ strikes. The networks have been slow to commit to their schedules, still rejiggering their lineups for September and beyond. Cable outlets have been bumping the release dates of in-the-can shows, lest they wither without promotion by their stars, an activity prohibited by the actors’ guild during the strike. The streaming archives beckon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea Finds New Leverage in the Ukraine War
description: Kim Jong-un is likely to seek missile and warhead technology in an expected visit to Russia, and he is already getting a public embrace he has long sought.
content: For Kim Jong-un, the leader of North Korea, a rare trip to Russia this month to discuss military aid for President Vladimir V. Putin’s Ukraine war effort could provide two things the North has wanted for a long time: technical help with its weapons programs, and to finally be needed by an important neighbor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: He Wanted His Texas Home to Resemble a ‘Groovy’ Opium Den
description: His designer was taken aback. But then she set about creating “Lenny Kravitz meets Italian ’60s meets ‘Once Upon a Time in Hollywood.’”
content: When Kirk Ferguson asked Sara Story to design the interiors of his new house in Austin, Texas, his request was unlike any she had heard before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Markets Remain Anxious, Despite Falling Odds of a Recession
description: Some economists are playing down the chances of a downturn. But investors and voters aren’t feeling nearly as optimistic.
content: For the third time in three months, economists at Goldman Sachs have lowered the odds of a recession and now put the risk of a downturn in the United States at 15 percent. Yet despite the upbeat outlook, which follows other votes of confidence from Wall Street in recent weeks, global stocks and U.S. futures are in the red on Tuesday morning as inflation fears persist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Gloria Coates, Composer Who Defied Conventions, Dies at 89
description: A Wisconsin native, she was among the most prolific female composers of symphonies, 17 in all, finding particular prominence in Europe, where she lived.
content: Gloria Coates, an adventurous composer who wrote symphonies — she was one of the few women to do so — as well as other works, pieces that were seldom performed in her home country, the United States, but found audiences in Europe, where she lived much of her professional life, died on Aug. 19 in Munich. She was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: 3 Bullets, 2 Wars, 1 Village
description: The legacy of World War II lingers in the Ukrainian town of Kamianka, where tractors spit out shell casings, old and new. Now it has been destroyed by a new conflict.
content: The woman pointed at a muddy, half-broken bucket, gesturing to a visitor to look inside. Her home had been destroyed after the Russians invaded in 2022 but she was pointing to detritus from the last war to sweep through this part of eastern Ukraine: shell casings from World War II.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Ghostwriter Returns With an A.I. Travis Scott Song, and Industry Allies
description: The anonymous artist, who stirred conversation with the A.I. track “Heart on My Sleeve,” has been quietly consulting with executives, while also gunning for a Grammy.
content: Earlier this year, when the anonymous musical creator known as Ghostwriter released an unauthorized track that used artificial intelligence voice effects to mimic the pop superstars Drake and the Weeknd, the fallout was immediate and far-reaching.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: No Luck With Misi Reservations? Cook Missy Robbins’s Pasta at Home.
description: A founder of the Surf Lodge in Montauk debuts a clubby SoHo spot, Taste56 opens a bar and more restaurant news.
content: “My dream project for 25 years,” is how Missy Robbins described the latest addition to Lilia and Misi, the Brooklyn places she owns with Sean Feeney. “I always intended to open a store,” she added, referring to an outlet for her fresh pastas, jarred vegetables and other products. She introduced the packaged goods in 2019, but, because of the pandemic, sold them only online in the restaurants. Though the new spot — a compact storefront and kitchen with retail shelves up front, seating for 22 and a shady garden in back — has a menu and accepts limited reservations to allow for walk-ins, she considers it to be primarily a shop. “I want people to come and buy pasta and try it at home,” she said. Need help? She has two cookbooks, also on sale. As for dining in, a recent menu featured assorted vegetables, like marinated eggplant, and grilled artichokes with Provolone and hot peppers on a sesame roll; and also prosciutto di Parma with fontina gougères, and mozzarella in carrozza. The pasta dish of the day was spaghetti with bottarga, lemon and garlic bread crumbs. The menu changes frequently.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell
title: Pork Industry Grapples With Whiplash of Shifting Regulations
description: Retailers in California, and pig farmers and processors thousands of miles away, are bracing for the impact of a state ban on some sources of the meat.
content: These were supposed to be boom times for Pederson’s Natural Farms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: The Glorious History of the Erie Canal
description: One trip through the locks will convince you: It is truly an emblem of American ingenuity and grit.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today, we bring you a brief history lesson on the amazing Erie Canal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman and Tiffany Hsu
title: Margaritaville Aims to Hang On After Jimmy Buffett’s Death
description: The musician and his carefree vacation vibes inspired a business empire. Can it go on without its founder?
content: Jimmy Buffett, who died of cancer on Friday, was many things: a singer, a songwriter and a spokesman for tropical escape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Aaron Boxerman
title: As Saudis Consider Deal With Israel, Palestinians Seek Sway in Talks
description: The Palestinian leadership condemned efforts in 2020 to end Israel’s diplomatic isolation in the Arab world. Now, in the face of similar moves, they are trying a new tack.
content: When a group of three Arab states forged landmark diplomatic ties with Israel in 2020, the Palestinian leadership saw the process as a betrayal: The deals upended a decades-old Arab practice of ostracizing Israel until the creation of a Palestinian state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Zach Bryan’s Self-Titled Album Is His First No. 1
description: The singer-songwriter, whose music crosses genre borders, also has the first rock release to top the Billboard 200 in over a year.
content: Zach Bryan, the Oklahoma-raised singer-songwriter whose work fits somewhere on a continuum of country, rock and Americana folk, has logged his first No. 1 album and single with big streaming numbers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: The New Reality for College Dining Halls: Dozens of Dietary Restrictions
description: A surge of students with allergies and special diets is challenging meal services and changing the shape of the campus cafeteria.
content: For the staff of the Michigan State University dining halls, serving roughly 27,000 students each semester has never been a picnic. But these days, the job involves an even bigger challenge: One in six of those students has an allergy or other dietary restriction. Just five years ago, it was one in eight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. Petrilli
title: We Can Only Fight Learning Loss With Accountability And Action
description: Let’s bring back an era of accountability.
content: The bad news about U.S. schools just keeps coming. We already knew from federal studies that students lost significant ground during the Covid pandemic and its related school shutdowns. What’s alarming about the latest research, published in July by the research organization NWEA, is that American children continued backsliding over the most recent school year, making less progress in reading and math than their counterparts before the pandemic. Rather than catching up, our students are falling further behind, succumbing to “education’s long Covid,” as the researchers put it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Workers Plow Through Great Wall of China, Leaving a Hole
description: The pair, a 38-year-old man and 55-year-old woman, used an excavator to widen an existing gap and make a shortcut, the authorities said.
content: Two workers have been detained in northern China after local authorities said they plowed through a section of the country’s Great Wall with an excavator, leaving a gaping hole.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Restaurant Review: All New York Bistros Steal. Libertine Steals From the Right Places.
description: In a city full of second-generation Gallic knockoffs, this West Village newcomer cooks and looks like the real thing.
content: There is a type of New York bistro that people like because it reminds them of other New York bistros. Some of the older examples of this type were built in imitation of actual places in the real France, but some of the younger ones didn’t go that far away for inspiration. They just looked around at Manhattan’s other bistros, brasseries and bistro-brasseries. (The line between the two, still sharp in France, has always been blurred here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: What Turned New Jersey’s Pools Green? A Man and His Drone, Police Say.
description: A local business owner used damaging chemicals to turn multiple swimming pools yellow and green over the course of the summer, according to the police, who said he was likely “pranking people.”
content: Sandra Woolstion decided enough was enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Matthew Goldstein
title: Bread, Water and Peanut Butter: Sam Bankman-Fried’s Life in Jail
description: Mr. Bankman-Fried, founder of the failed cryptocurrency exchange FTX, has protested his conditions at Brooklyn’s Metropolitan Detention Center as he awaits trial on fraud charges.
content: A diet of bread, water and peanut butter. A laptop with no internet connection. And intermittent access to millions of pages of digital evidence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Murdaugh’s Lawyers Seek New Trial, Saying Clerk Tampered With Jury
description: Lawyers for Alex Murdaugh, a South Carolina lawyer convicted of murder, said in a court filing that an official told jurors not to be “fooled by” his testimony.
content: When Alex Murdaugh, the once-influential South Carolina lawyer, was convicted in March of murdering his wife and younger son, the verdict was widely seen as a rebuke of corruption in a legal system that Mr. Murdaugh had bent to his benefit for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David C. Adams
title: Key Suspect in Assassination of Haiti President Is Set to Plead Guilty
description: A former Colombian Army captain who is accused of playing a leading role in the 2021 killing will change his plea to guilty, a sign that he may testify against his co-defendants.
content: A key defendant in the trial of the men charged in the assassination of President Jovenel Moïse of Haiti is set to plead guilty this week, in what could be a major breakthrough for U.S. prosecutors who are handling the case in Miami federal court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: Record Rains Flood Greece Just as Wildfires Let Up
description: The deluge caused extensive damage and a death in Greece, just as firefighters contained blazes there. Floods in Bulgaria and Turkey also led to six fatalities in total.
content: Torrential rain unleashed major floods in Central Greece on Tuesday that submerged streets and wreaked widespread damage, just as firefighters were containing enormous wildfires in the country. One man died, and at least one person was missing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Spectator Is Removed From U.S. Open After Remark Associated With Nazi Regime
description: Alexander Zverev, from Germany, told the umpire that the man had said the phrase. He was escorted out after the “disparaging remark,” a spokesman said.
content: A spectator at the U.S. Open was removed early on Tuesday after Alexander Zverev, a player from Germany, told the umpire that he had heard the man say a phrase associated with the Nazi regime, according to a spokesman and a video of the encounter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: ‘That’s Valor’: Biden Awards Medal of Honor to Vietnam-Era Army Pilot
description: First Lt. Larry L. Taylor, whose helicopter was running out of fuel and ammunition, rescued four soldiers who were taking intense enemy fire in Vietnam.
content: The four American soldiers were pinned down in June 1968, taking intense fire from the enemy near the hamlet of Ap Go Cong in Vietnam. The large Huey helicopter sent to rescue them had abandoned its attempt, citing the great likelihood of failure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: What Were the Best and Worst Parts of Your Summer Vacation?
description: Did you attend a concert, eat a delicious meal, deal with extreme weather or partake in the movie event of the year? Whatever was most memorable for you, we want to hear about it.
content: As September rolls around and school starts back up again, we want to know: What were the best and worst parts of your summer vacation?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘All Women Are Psychic’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: I pull up to the neon-lit drive-through past midnight. The young cashier inside the fluorescent box calls me “honey,” as if we weren’t around the same age. “Hospital?” she asks. I blink — convinced that all women are psychic. “Your bracelet!” she says, pointing to my wrist. “Three hours to see someone for my womb,” I tell her. (With endometriosis and ovarian cysts, I feel that it is more “wound” than womb.) We talk, discovering that we both have insufficient health care, no primary doctor. “I’m tired,” I tell her. Her dark-lined eyes meet mine. “Girl,” she says, “me too.” — Britt Gillman
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: You Can’t Normalize Relations With a Government That Isn’t Normal
description: In the quest for a peace and security deal, the U.S. and Saudi Arabia cannot let Netanyahu turn them into useful idiots.
content: The more I learn about the complex peace and security deal that the Biden team is trying to put together between the United States, Saudi Arabia, Israel and the Palestinians, the more I’m convinced that if they pull it off, they’ll win both the Nobel Peace Prize and the Nobel Prize in Physics. Because finding a way to balance the different interests of all four of these parties makes quantum mechanics look as easy as tic-tac-toe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Suhasini Raj
title: Making Sure 1.4 Billion People Are Very Aware India Is Hosting the G20
description: With wall-to-wall promotion and a barnstorming flair, India’s governing party is milking the lead-up to this weekend’s summit for all it’s worth.
content: In cities across India, the beaming face of Prime Minister Narendra Modi adorns giant posters promoting the country’s G20 presidency. A hundred national monuments, including the Red Fort in Delhi, were illuminated with the G20 logo to encourage people to post selfies. Government reading lessons inform students that India is a fitting G20 host because it is “the Fountain Head of Democracy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Was Big Stimulus a Big Mistake?
description: Inflation is down, employment is up. Where’s the damage?
content: U.S. economic policy in 2021 was met with a firestorm of criticism from many economists. I’m not talking just about Republican loyalists, who always predict disaster when a Democrat moves into the White House. Even Democratic economists, or relatively apolitical technocrats, were scathing in their denunciations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Tennessee Democrat Who Took Part in Gun Violence Protest Will Run for Senate
description: Gloria Johnson, who barely avoided expulsion for her role in a gun control rally in the State Legislature, is hoping to unseat Senator Marsha Blackburn, a Republican.
content: Gloria Johnson, a Democratic state representative from Tennessee who narrowly avoided being expelled from the Legislature in April after taking part in a gun control protest on the statehouse floor, announced plans on Tuesday to run for the U.S. Senate seat held by Senator Marsha Blackburn, a Republican.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Blackouts Pit a Utility Against Residents (and Pot Farms)
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, September 5, 2023.
content: “People are dying here because they don’t have light. We can’t just point to the marijuana and say, ‘Here’s the culprit.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Sean Keenan
title: Dozens of ‘Cop City’ Activists Are Indicted on Racketeering Charges
description: Opponents of a police training facility in Atlanta say they are engaged in legitimate acts of protest. Prosecutors accuse them of taking part in a sprawling criminal enterprise.
content: More than 60 activists who challenged a planned Atlanta police and fire training complex have been indicted by a Georgia grand jury in a sprawling racketeering case, accused of engaging in violence, intimidation and property destruction as part of a campaign to stall construction of the facility known by its critics as Cop City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Abend
title: 5 Hot Springs in Iceland That Aren’t the Blue Lagoon
description: Some say Iceland’s more than 600 geothermal springs are the secret to its citizens’ happiness. Here’s a selection of scenic waters in and around Reykjavik where you can test that theory.
content: Early on a Sunday morning in July, two brothers from Boston sat on Reykjavik’s rocky coast, with their faces turned toward the chilly waters of the bay and their feet soaking in what felt like a warm bath. Ben and Lucas Zheng had landed around 4:30 a.m. at Iceland’s international airport, and didn’t have too many early-morning options for how to spend the start of their eight-hour layover before flying on to Venice. So, taking advantage of the season’s round-the-clock daylight, they walked 40 minutes from the city center toward the northwestern tip of the Seltjarnarnes peninsula. There on the stony beach, they rolled up their pants and sat for a couple of hours, their legs submerged in the naturally warm Kvika pool, which, at 12 inches deep, is more foot bath than hot tub.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: New York City’s Crackdown on Airbnb Is Starting. Here’s What to Expect.
description: On Tuesday, the city will start enforcing strict new rules on how and when New Yorkers can rent out homes using platforms like Airbnb and Vrbo.
content: New York City officials on Tuesday are expected to start enforcing strict new regulations that limit residents’ ability to rent out homes through platforms like Airbnb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: No Trump, Not Much Biden: The Ad Wars in 3 Governor’s Races
description: Offering a look at both parties’ political strategies this year, the ads focus largely on issues like education, the economy, jobs and taxes, as well as local scandals and crime.
content: Just over a year before the 2024 elections, three races for governor in Kentucky, Louisiana and Mississippi are offering a window into the parties’ political strategies and how they might approach statewide and congressional contests next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Northern Ireland Police Chief Resigns Amid Mounting Scandals
description: A data breach and a court ruling have piled pressure on a police force that was founded on a promise to move past sectarian strife.
content: The top police official in Northern Ireland resigned on Monday after a series of scandals, raising questions about police leadership in a region where law enforcement has long been a contentious issue, and prompting calls for further changes in the force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: At Telluride, the Performances Speak Volumes Even if the Actors Can’t
description: In films like “All of Us Strangers,” “Poor Things” and “Rustin,” vivid turns kept audiences rapt even as the Hollywood strikes made it a less starry affair.
content: Over a holiday weekend dedicated to labor, this year’s Telluride Film Festival attendees couldn’t help being reminded of striking workers: the members of SAG-AFTRA, the television and film actors’ union currently in a standoff with the Hollywood studios. It wasn’t merely the absence of performers at pre- and post-screening events — or at the restaurants, parties and public conversations conducted in the park right off the main street of the former mining town. It was more that their presence onscreen made such a strong argument for the gifts they have brought to what is fast becoming a vintage year in film.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla Guo
title: In Chaotic Rhode Island Primary, 11 Democrats Vie for a House Seat
description: The vote on Tuesday will almost certainly determine who will succeed former Representative David Cicilline, and could hold clues to what voters are looking for in the run-up to 2024.
content: Days before a Democratic primary that will almost certainly decide who represents her in Congress, Linda Vaughan Dubois of Rumford, R.I., still had not decided on a candidate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: Planned talks between Vladimir Putin and Kim Jong-un.
content: Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, plans to travel to Vladivostok, Russia, this month to meet with Vladimir Putin, Russia’s leader, to discuss military cooperation, including the possibility of supplying Russia with weaponry for its war in Ukraine, foreign officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kati Marton
title: Life During Cold Wartime in East Berlin
description: In “Beyond the Wall,” the historian Katja Hoyer draws on archives and interviews to bring the eastern half of Germany back into the postwar picture.
content: Only one place in the former Soviet bloc has a word that denotes nostalgia for the mostly unlamented Empire. The place is eastern Germany, and the word is Ostalgie. A string of small Ostalgie shops in the former East features the old communist brands of pickles and mustard — as well as models of the smoke-spewing Trabant cars — for those who long to reminisce about the bad old days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Schools Closed as Manhunt for Pennsylvania Fugitive Expands
description: Danelo Cavalcante escaped from a prison near Philadelphia on Thursday, days after receiving a life sentence for murder. The authorities said he had been spotted near homes.
content: Two school districts in Pennsylvania canceled classes on Tuesday as troopers searched by land and air for a convicted murderer who was spotted near residential areas after escaping from a prison near Philadelphia last week, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Cerceo
title: Want to Understand Clean Energy Anxiety? Look at the Jersey Shore.
description: We need to meet people resisting wind and solar power with gentleness and curiosity.
content: Earlier this summer, as my children splashed in the freakishly warm ocean waves by the beautiful Victorian seaside town of Cape May, N.J, angry protesters gathered a few towns away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: What Have We Learned From a Summer of Climate Reckoning?
description: Kate Marvel discusses what the latest climate science reveals about this summer’s heat waves and extreme weather events.
content: This summer has been a parade of broken climate records. June was the hottest June and July was not just the hottest July but the hottest month ever on record. At the same time, it looks like we are at the start of a green revolution: Decarbonization efforts have gone far better than what many had hoped for just a few years ago, and renewable energy is getting cheaper.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: David Wallace-Wells Interviews Kate Marvel
description: The Sep. 5, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode, guest-hosted by David Wallace-Wells, with Kate Marvel. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Collier Schorr and Sasha Kelly
title: Men’s Wear Goes Back to School
description: This fall, collegiate staples — cardigans, crisp button-downs and pinstriped suits — take a rebellious turn when paired with vintage jewelry and tank tops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: How Ava DuVernay Made ‘Origin’ an Adaptation of the Best Seller ‘Caste’
description: The nonfiction best seller explores race and hierarchy but doesn’t suggest a straightforward screen story. For her film, DuVernay got creative.
content: “I’ve never even seen that beach!” said Ava DuVernay as she took in the view on Monday at a hotel restaurant on the Lido, the island where the Venice Film Festival is held. Staring out onto the sands, DuVernay smiled. “I’ve been to Venice a couple of times, but I never went to the beach,” she said. “I was more into the canals, but this is fantastic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: Applying to N.Y.C. Public Schools Can Feel Daunting. Here’s What to Know.
description: What matters when choosing a school? How should you compare options? And what’s the best strategy for getting your first choice?
content: In New York City, school admissions season, which starts not long after the first day of school, is a chaotic, monthslong frenzy for many families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan
title: New Yorkers Sweat It Out During Post-Labor Day Heat Wave
description: From the city’s public pools to the U.S. Open, New Yorkers experienced unusually high temperatures for early September, and some places in the surrounding area broke heat records.
content: School is about to start, pumpkin-spice coffee is back on the menu, and New York City’s public pools close for the season in less than a week, but city residents are encountering some of the most sweltering heat of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: The Artistry of Her Baskets Is Complex. So Is the Story Around Them.
description: A couple recognized the Washoe weaver Louisa Keyser’s prodigious talent and spun myths to promote it. But her fortitude shines in work that today can be seen in museums and at the Independent 20th Century fair.
content: The Native American baskets sold in the early 1900s out of Abe Cohn’s Emporium, a men’s clothing store in Carson City, Nev., were exceptional. They were woven by Dat So La Lee, said to be a “princess” from the nearby Washoe people whose royal status permitted her alone to utilize a special weaving style.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Saudi Arabia and Russia Extend Oil Production Cuts Through December
description: The move reflected renewed efforts by the two major exporters to bolster the price of crude.
content: Saudi Arabia and Russia, in coordinated statements, said on Tuesday that they would extend their cuts in oil supplies through the rest of 2023.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Canada Tries Leaders of Anti-Vaccine Protest That Jammed Ottawa
description: Two key organizers of the 2022 trucker protest argued that their efforts were a form of free speech, as prosecutors asserted that “this case is not about their political views.”
content: A criminal trial opened on Tuesday for two Canadians who were key organizers of the trucker convoy that paralyzed the country’s capital, Ottawa, for nearly a month in early 2022, upturning the lives of many residents and creating economic hardship for local businesses and workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Alex Stern, Stella Tan, Rob Szypko, Shannon Lin, Lexie Diao, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Alyssa Moxley
title: Passenger Planes Nearly Collide Far More Than You Know
description: A Times investigation found an alarming pattern of safety lapses and near misses in the skies.
content: A Times investigation found that U.S. passenger planes come dangerously close to crashing into each other far more frequently than the public knows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Chinese Cars Star at Munich Auto Show, Underscoring German Economic Woes
description: China, an electric-vehicle juggernaut, will have at least seven brands on display, while Germany’s automakers are now a drag on their home economy.
content: For decades, the phrase “Made in Germany” signaled cutting-edge automotive technology and design. But now German automakers are falling behind in the global race to produce more electric vehicles, and some executives are using a new catchphrase to describe how quickly they need to catch up: “China speed.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno and Neal E. Boudette
title: U.S. Seeks to Recall 52 Million Airbag Inflaters
description: The action covers airbags made by two companies and used by 12 automakers from 2000 to 2018. The parts were linked to seven injuries and one death.
content: Federal auto safety regulators moved Tuesday toward a recall of about 52 million airbag inflaters used by a dozen major carmakers, calling the parts unsafe and susceptible to rupture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Moffitt
title: Out West, the Gay Cowboy Roams Free
description: The frontier has long been a symbol of American masculinity. Now a rising generation of artists are creating a new queer mythology.
content: TWO MEN, A grizzled sheriff and a gunslinging vigilante, confront each other in a dusty saloon town. It’s a scene familiar from countless western films, but in Pedro Almodóvar’s new short, “Strange Way of Life,” in theaters next month, only a few minutes elapse before the two characters end up in bed together. When Silva (Pedro Pascal) visits his former lover Jake (Ethan Hawke), he rekindles their romance before revealing less amorous intentions. Intrigue ensues, and the shock of two gay cowboys gives way to what we might expect from a classic western: shootouts, horseback chases, fugitive justice. Almodóvar’s second film in English forgoes the melodrama for which he is best known, adhering instead to genre traditions, so “the interrupted and then resumed love story between these two men will be taken more seriously,” the 73-year-old Spanish director says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Why So Many Americans Are So Down on Biden
description: Headlines and statistics don’t always capture what people see in their everyday lives.
content: Unemployment is near historic lows, and inflation has come way down. We are inflicting a strategic humiliation on Russia by arming Ukraine without putting American forces at risk. The homicide rate fell by about 10 percent across 30 cities compared with last year. Democrats defied electoral trends by holding the Senate, scoring major legislative victories and easily confirming a Supreme Court nominee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Krysten Chambrot
title: Simple Recipes That Are Short on Budget, Big on Flavor
description: Eric Kim’s shrimp fried rice puts those freezer goodies to good use, and kimchi chicken lettuce wraps come together with just five ingredients (and 25 minutes).
content: Hello, weeknight fans! This is Krysten, stepping in for Emily. Is this your first day back from vacation? You’re not alone. Here in New York, the last weeks of August feel so desolate that I half-expect a tumbleweed to cross my path. Then, come early September, everyone is back from their summery reveries, ready to get down to business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Walther
title: The N.F.L.’s New Kickoff Rule Is a Classically Terrible Idea
description: I fear the wrath of the football gods.
content: There is no English noun that adequately conveys what millions of fans experience on the eve of the pro football season. Only something like the ancient Greek concept of ataraxia — which literally means the absence of disturbance or trouble but connotes a kind of sublime contentedness — begins to approach our exquisite feeling of detachment from all worldly cares. The N.F.L. makes ataraxia available to each and every one of us three days a week, which should number high among the otherwise dubious achievements of late modernity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Chaundler
title: Coach of Spain’s Women’s Soccer Team Is Fired
description: Players had accused the coach, Jorge Vilda, of outdated methods and controlling behavior. His boss, Luis Rubiales, is still embroiled in scandal over a nonconsensual kiss.
content: The coach of the Spanish national soccer team that won the Women’s World Cup trophy last month was ousted on Tuesday by the country’s soccer federation, after months of complaints from players who accused him of outdated methods and controlling behavior.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Tough
title: Americans Are Losing Faith in the Value of College. Whose Fault Is That?
description: For most people, the new economics of higher ed make going to college a risky bet.
content: A decade or so ago, Americans were feeling pretty positive about higher education. Public-opinion polls in the early 2010s all told the same story. In one survey, 86 percent of college graduates said that college had been a good investment; in another, 74 percent of young adults said a college education was “very important”; in a third, 60 percent of Americans said that colleges and universities were having a positive impact on the country. Ninety-six percent of parents who identified as Democrats said they expected their kids to attend college — only to be outdone by Republican parents, 99 percent of whom said they expected their kids to go to college.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 5, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Sept. 5, 2023.
content: An article on Saturday about Paris’s ban on e-scooters referred incorrectly to e-scooter accidents there in 2022. There were 459 people injured and three people killed in accidents involving e-scooters; the e-scooters did not kill three people and injure 459 others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Hemingway Survived Two Plane Crashes. A Letter About Them Just Sold for Over $237,000.
description: “I am weak from so much internal bleeding,” the novelist wrote to his lawyer. “Have been a good boy and tried to rest.”
content: A four-page letter that Ernest Hemingway wrote to his lawyer after the writer survived two back-to-back plane crashes in East Africa in 1954 sold at auction for $237,055, according to Nate Sanders Auctions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Get Ready for the New Gucci, and Other Surprises of the Fashion Season
description: It’s going to be something to see, from designer debuts to the celebrities on the front rows.
content: It’s fashion month! The news may be full of Trump indictments, extreme weather and war, but the shows stop for almost no crisis (pandemics excepted). For anyone in need of a moment of escape or some inspiration to gird yourself for the day, they may, in fact, represent an increasingly important pressure valve. There’s a reason, after the Covid lockdowns, the shows have returned in full, or even greater, force — not just as industry events, but as full-fledged entertainment happenings that are extending their tentacles far beyond the runway. So prepare yourself for approximately four weeks of impossibly glamorous photos, street style and gossip. Here’s what you need to know:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fernanda  Eberstadt
title: A Queer Poet’s Bittersweet Trip Across Russia to Return Home
description: Oksana Vasyakina’s first novel is a family history and a reflection on womanhood.
content: “Wound,” Oksana Vasyakina’s debut novel, recounts a road trip that is both an elegy to the dead and a homecoming. Its heroine, who like the author is a prizewinning Russian poet and L.G.B.T.Q. activist named Oksana Vasyakina, has watched over the death of her mother, Angella, from breast cancer. Now Oksana is transporting her mother’s ashes 3,000 miles from a steppe town in western Russia to Ust-Ilimsk, the industrial city in the Siberian taiga that was their hometown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: This Year’s U.S. Open Belongs to Coco Gauff, Win or Lose
description: It has become clear that Gauff, at age 19, is the queen of this U.S. Open.
content: It’s Sunday evening, a little after 6 o’clock, and Coco Gauff is going through her postmatch routine in the section of the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center where players warm up before matches and cool down after them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: NPR C.E.O. to Retire at Year’s End
description: John Lansing, who has run the broadcaster for four years, said it was now in the early stages of a national search for his successor.
content: NPR’s chief executive, John Lansing, said on Tuesday that he would retire at the end of the year, ending a rocky four years atop the public broadcaster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero, Andre Paultre and Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Can Kenya Bring Order to Haiti? Doubts Are Swirling.
description: The African country has volunteered to send forces to Haiti as its security crisis spirals out of control. But the plan is facing pushback.
content: Every day, Vélina Élysée Charlier drives past barricaded neighborhoods and frequently sees dead bodies lying on the street, she said, a result of score-settling between gangs and vigilantes in Haiti’s capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Glanz and Josh Holder
title: Earthquake sensors are helping document Russian bombings in new detail.
description: The explosions came one after another, a relentless series of bombings that echoed across Kyiv in the first weeks of the war. Residents at the center of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine were forced underground into makeshift shelters.
content: The explosions came one after another, a relentless series of bombings that echoed across Kyiv in the first weeks of the war. Residents at the center of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine were forced underground into makeshift shelters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: Ukraine’s Forces Try to Punch 2nd Hole in Russian Lines
description: Ukrainian soldiers are trying to build on a new breach in enemy lines, but the battle will not be easy, military analysts said.
content: Ukrainian forces, churning slowly forward after breaching Russia’s initial defensive lines in the occupied south, are turning their attention to breaking through in another heavily defended patch of territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caroline Hopkins
title: How Do I Get Rid of Toenail Fungus?
description: As unsightly as it is, the infection is usually manageable — but only with the right treatment. Here’s how to kick it.
content: Q: It looks like I have fungus beneath my toenail, but how can I be sure? Does toenail fungus go away on its own?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour Speed Round, Part 2
description: A conversation about Swift’s relationship to celebrity, the tour date as destination event and how fans dressed up for the show.
content: The first leg of Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour has come to a close, with the pop superstar having performed in stadiums across North America for several million people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Former Proud Boys Leader Sentenced to 22 Years
description: Also, a very American U.S. Open. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: Enrique Tarrio, the former leader of the far-right Proud Boys, was sentenced this afternoon to 22 years in prison for organizing a gang of his pro-Trump followers to attack the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and stop the peaceful transfer of presidential power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: McConnell Releases New Health Assurances From the Capitol’s Physician
description: With the Senate returning from its long summer recess, the minority leader circulated a note from the congressional doctor saying an examination and tests showed no signs of a stroke or seizure.
content: Hoping to reassure his colleagues that he is physically able to continue as minority leader, Senator Mitch McConnell released a letter on Tuesday from the attending physician of Congress declaring that an examination and tests had ruled out a stroke or seizure as causes of his recent on-camera medical episodes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miranda S. Spivack
title: An Evolving Salt Lake City Hopes to Be ‘Just Like Austin’
description: Shedding its stodgy image, the city has become a destination for start-ups looking for cheaper space and younger workers on the hunt for roomier housing.
content: When Dino Fusco began traveling to Salt Lake City in the early 2000s for Goldman Sachs’s real estate arm, the odds of finding a coffee shop or brewpub were essentially zero. The influence of the generally conservative Mormon community over state politics and social issues made alcohol and caffeine scarce.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Everlasting Pain of Losing a Child
description: Responses to Sarah Wildman’s essay about life after her child’s death. Also: Clarence Thomas; political novices; lanternflies; ignoring the truth about Donald Trump.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Federal Court Again Strikes Down Alabama’s Congressional Map
description: Republicans failed to comply with a court order to create a second majority Black district or something “close to it,” the judicial panel said.
content: A panel of federal judges rejected Alabama’s latest congressional map on Tuesday, ruling that a new map needed to be drawn because Republican lawmakers had failed to comply with orders to create a second majority Black district or something “close to it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: Kim and Putin Plan to Meet, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hanya Yanagihara
title: The Burden of Inheritance
description: How do designers and artists continue the legacy of others without losing their own voice?
content: Anyone lucky enough to become the steward of a storied business knows that learning you’ve been chosen to lead a legendary institution, fashion house, business or publication inspires two immediate reactions. The first is excitement. The second is fear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Sloan
title: Books Recommended With Uncommon Wisdom and Tender Care
description: Five yearning Tokyo readers get life advice with their borrowed volumes in Michiko Aoyama’s “What You Are Looking For Is in the Library.”
content: Here is a novel about the bone-deep thrill of things working out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura May Todd
title: In Tuscany, a Dinner to Celebrate Black Queer Artists
description: Jordan Anderson, the founder of the MQBMBQ residency, hosted friends and collaborators to toast a fruitful summer in the Italian countryside.
content: On a July night in rural Italy, despite a stifling heat wave, a row of dinner guests danced in their seats at a long wooden table. Beyoncé’s latest album, “Renaissance,” pumped out of hidden speakers and, as the sun sank behind the olive groves in the distance, servers brought out bottles of Sangiovese wine and baskets of focaccia. It was the final week of the summer artist residency program at Villa Lena, a boutique hotel and farm stay in Tuscany, and the guests were celebrating a peaceful, productive month in the countryside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ned Blackhawk
title: Tracing the Origins of American Racism as a Path to Healing
description: In “The Hidden Roots of White Supremacy,” Robert P. Jones explores the harmful legacy of a 15th-century Christian doctrine used to justify expansion and colonization in the New World.
content: When Joe Biden became the first sitting U.S. president to use the term “white supremacy” — in a 2021 speech commemorating the 100th anniversary of the Tulsa race massacre — he gave voice to the views of countless other Americans who share his concern about the country’s often forgotten histories of racial violence. “
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: exacerbate
description: This word has appeared in 205 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word exacerbate has appeared in 205 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 10 in “Heat Singes the Mind, Not Just the Body” by Apoorva Mandavilli_:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: After Mass Killing of Trees on a Wealthy Waterfront, a Theory Takes Hold
description: The brazen culling of more than 250 trees at a waterside reserve in Australia, the speculation goes, had the goal of producing a better view.
content: The crime scene: Nearly an acre of protected bush land in a wealthy suburb of Sydney, bracketed by sprawling multimillion-dollar mansions on one side and the sparkling harbor on the other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard W. Bauer
title: It’s Not Pro-Life to Oppose a Program That Has Saved 25 Million Lives
description: Despite what some House Republicans say, PEPFAR has nothing to do with abortion.
content: In 1997, the global AIDS crisis was growing more dire by the day. That year, I was on a mission as a Roman Catholic priest and social worker to help care for people with H.I.V. in Tanzania.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: Tropical Storm Lee Forms in the Atlantic. But It’s Too Soon to Worry.
description: Tropical Depression 13 just became a named storm, amid social media speculation about a possible big East Coast storm. But a lot of variables would need to line up before people need to worry.
content: Over the Labor Day weekend, social media feeds flooded with stark warnings about a major storm slamming the East Coast of the United States next week. That hypothetical storm just became Tropical Storm Lee with sustained winds of 45 miles per hour on Tuesday afternoon, according to the National Hurricane Center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miranda Stern
title: A Final Goodbye to Opiates
description: A filmmaker captures her attempt to come off the synthetic opiates that kept her off heroin for the past six years.
content: For most of my adult life, I’ve struggled with an opiate addiction of some form. But I’m one of the lucky ones, because I’m still here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Have You Met My Collaborator? He’s So Classic, He’s Dead.
description: Remaking a vintage musical for the 2020s takes guts, sensitivity and perhaps a medium.
content: Musicals can be shotgun weddings, their authors joined by necessity, not love. But in most cases, they’re at least both breathing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Buyer of Trump’s Truth Social Gets More Time to Complete Merger
description: Shareholders in a shell company that has been trying for nearly two years to merge with former President Donald Trump’s media company approved a 12-month extension to complete the deal.
content: Shareholders of a cash-rich shell company approved a measure on Tuesday that will give the firm 12 additional months to complete its long-delayed merger with former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: First Lady Tests Positive for Covid, but President Does Not
description: Jill Biden was experiencing mild symptoms and recovering at the family home in Delaware, the White House said. President Biden returned to Washington after her diagnosis.
content: Jill Biden, the first lady, tested positive for Covid-19, the White House announced late Monday night, but she is experiencing only mild symptoms and will remain at the family home in Rehoboth Beach, Del., where she and President Biden spent part of the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 7 New Songs You Should Hear Now
description: Listen to recent releases from Noname, Al Green, Sufjan Stevens and more.
content: The day after Labor Day has got to be one of the worst days in the American calendar year. (Not quite as bad as the first workday after New Year’s, but worth mentioning in the same breath.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Where Are the Students?
description: Attendance at school has come to feel more optional than it did before the pandemic.
content: If you’re a child — or a former child — you know how hard it can be to summon the energy to leave the house each day for school. It’s early in the morning, and you are tired. Maybe you have a test or a social situation that’s making you anxious. Staying in bed often seems easier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talmon Joseph Smith
title: Wrestling With Inequality, Some Conservatives Redraw Economic Blueprint
description: A growing number of Republican politicians and theorists are challenging party orthodoxy on pocketbook issues, corporate power and government’s role.
content: More Republicans are coming to the view that economic inequality, or a lack of social mobility, is a problem in the United States — and that more can be done to enable families to attain or regain a middle-class life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Linda Evangelista, ’90s Supermodel, Had Breast Cancer Twice in 5 Years
description: She disclosed her health challenges in an interview with The Wall Street Journal Magazine.
content: Linda Evangelista, the supermodel made famous in the 1990s, revealed in an interview that she survived breast cancer twice in five years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Haramis, Lise Sarfati and Delphine Danhier
title: How Anthony Vaccarello Made Saint Laurent His Own
description: To leave his mark on the storied brand, the designer knew he’d have to honor the past — and defy it.
content: IMAGINE, IF YOU will, that it’s 2016 and you’re Anthony Vaccarello, a reserved and relatively untested fashion designer from Belgium. At 34, you’ve been hired as the new creative director of Saint Laurent, a half-century-old, billion-dollar French fashion house whose heavily mythologized founder, Yves Saint Laurent, created the modern woman’s wardrobe. Growing up, your only two dreams were to live in Paris, preferably with a view of the Eiffel Tower, and to make clothes. Without any industry connections, you managed to circumvent your greatest fear: a life of mediocrity. Your initial reaction is that you deserve this. Your second is, “Now what?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gonchar and Katherine Schulten
title: 8 Ways to Bring Birds and Birding Into Your Classroom
description: Look closely. Listen carefully. Ask questions. Gather data. Bird-watching helps students build essential academic skills and connect with the natural world.
content: The New York Times is running a citizen science birding project with the Cornell Lab of Ornithology. The goals are to gather observations about the birds in your area, fill in data gaps and give researchers a clearer picture of biodiversity. Why not have your students participate?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Claire Fu
title: Country Garden Makes $22.5 Million Payment, With $15 Billion to Go
description: The embattled Chinese property giant is said to have avoided default by meeting a deadline to pay interest on small loans. But it must repay billions within the next year.
content: Country Garden, China’s biggest property developer, told creditors that it had made a late interest payment, averting an immediate default on its debts and keeping the company financially viable for the time being.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Ex-Leader of Proud Boys Sentenced to 22 Years in Jan. 6 Sedition Case
description: The prison term for Enrique Tarrio was the most severe penalty handed down so far to any of the more than 1,100 people charged in connection with the Capitol attack.
content: Enrique Tarrio, the former leader of the Proud Boys, was sentenced on Tuesday to 22 years in prison for the central role he played in organizing a gang of his pro-Trump followers to attack the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and stop the peaceful transfer of presidential power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: South Korean Teachers Want an End to Parents’ Harassment
description: For months, tens of thousands of educators have protested nationwide against a rule they say keeps them from disciplining students for fear of being accused of child abuse.
content: Tens of thousands of teachers across South Korea have protested in the streets since July amid worsening complaints over student misbehavior and harassment by parents.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Dr. Brian P. Monahan, the attending physician of Congress, said in a letter on Tuesday that there was no evidence that Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the majority leader, had a seizure disorder or experienced a stroke last week.

title: A Colorado City Has Been Battling for Decades to Use Its Own Water
description: Lawsuits, protests and fierce disputes over who controls water in the parched American West have held up a crucial pipeline.

title: A Huge Threat to the U.S. Budget Has Receded. And No One Is Sure Why.
description: Instead of growing and growing, as it always had, spending per Medicare beneficiary has nearly leveled off over more than a decade.
content: Instead of growing and growing, as it always had, spending per Medicare beneficiary has nearly leveled off over more than a decade.

description: The designer Sara Story created a home with an aesthetic her client called “Lenny Kravitz meets Italian ’60s meets ‘Once Upon a Time in Hollywood.’”

author: By The New York Times
title: Army Pilot Who Fought in Vietnam Receives Medal of Honor
description: President Biden awarded First Lt. Larry L. Taylor the Medal of Honor, citing his “conspicuous gallantry” for rescuing fellow soldiers during the war in Vietnam.
content: President Biden awarded First Lt. Larry L. Taylor the Medal of Honor, citing his “conspicuous gallantry” for rescuing fellow soldiers during the war in Vietnam.

description: A filmmaker captures her attempt to come off the synthetic opiates that kept her off heroin for the past six years.
